dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON a BBC microphone of the 1920's, A formidable pie of machinery suspended on springs. A BBC NEWS READER, in a tuxedo with carnation boutonniere gargling while a TECHNICIAN holds a porcelain bowl and a towel at the ready. The man in the tuxedo expectorates discreetly into the bowl, wipes his mouth fastidiously, a signals to ANOTHER TECHNICIAN who produces an atomizer. T Reader opens his mouth, squeezes the rubber bulb, and spr his inner throat. Now, he’s ready. The reader speaks in flawless pear-shaped tones. There’s higher creature in the vocal world.

dialogues.speaker: BBC NEWS READER
dialogues.text: Good afternoon. This is the BBC National Programme and Empire Services taking you to Wembley Stadium for the Closing Ceremony of the Second and Final Season of the Empire Exhibition.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON a man's hand clutching a woman's hand. Woman’s mouth whispers into man's ear.

dialogues.speaker: BBC NEWS READER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: 58 British Colonies and Dominions have taken part, making this the largest Exhibition staged anywhere in the world. Complete with the new stadium, the Exhibition was built in Wembley, Middlesex at a cost of over 12 million pounds. The Exhibition has attracted over 27 million visitors from every corner of our great Empire and the rest of the world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Technicians in suits, ties and scientific looking overcoa wearing bulky headphones, monitor daunting banks of valve and dials while the Reader continues:

dialogues.speaker: BBC NEWS READER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Today the vast Stadium is filled to capacity with in excess of 100,000 spectators...as regiments from His Majesty's Army, Navy and Air Force stand in review.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nervous eyes flick towards a tunnel leading to a bright light. CLOSE ON - BERTIE - the Duke of York, second son of the K his handsome, sensitive, features look terrified.

dialogues.speaker: BBC NEWS READER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The Opening Ceremony was the first occasion his Majesty the King addressed his subjects on the wireless. The close of the first Season was the initial time His Royal Highness the Prince of Wales had broadcast. And today His Royal Highness the Duke of York will give his inaugural broadcast to the Nation and the World. WIDEN TO REVEAL his young wife, truly an English rose.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Time to go. He stares straight ahead, frozen. She gives him a loving peck on the cheek, quickly rubbing off a fleck of lipstic

dialogues.speaker: BBC NEWS READER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Leading us in prayer will be the Right Honourable and Most Reverend Archbishop of York, Primate of all England and Metropolitan. Now we go live to Wembley Stadium, where His Royal Highness the Duke of York will read his message from the King. COSMO LANG - comes up to Bertie. Tries to be helpful but makes him more nervous.

dialogues.speaker: COSMO LANG
dialogues.text: I am sure you will be splendid. Just take your time. The last bars of “God Save The King” echo down the corri ROBERT WOOD, the Chief BBC Engineer on Location whispers:

dialogues.speaker: WOOD
dialogues.text: Let the microphone do the work, sir. Wood checks his watch. WOOD (CONT’D) Thirty seconds, sir. Bertie braces his shoulders manfully, but without an ounc confidence, closes his eyes, nods, opens them, and reluctantly goes through the tunnel towards the light, li prize-fighter entering the arena, to be greeted by the ro of the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HAND-HELD CAMERA, BERTIE’S POV: far ahead, at a seemingly impossible distance, is the huge intimidating microphone, only thing between the terrified observer and 100,000 peo Silence falls over the stadium. Overhead, thick roiling clouds. BERTIE approaches...like a death march. Bertie’s eyes widen in terror as he reaches the microphon The red transmission light blinks four times then glows s red. Bertie is live.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Technicians stare at dials and listen to the hiss of sile The Reader and Floor Manager glance at each other nervous

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the tense silence PAN THROUGH some of the crowd waitin with growing discomfort. In particular we notice a father and son watching intently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bertie is frozen at the microphone. His neck and jaw musc contract and quiver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have received from his Majesty the K-K-K [For ease of reading, Bertie’s stammer will not be indica from this point in the script.] The stammer careens back at him, amplified and distorted the stadium PA system. CU huge metal speakers. CU soldiers at rigid attention. CU Wood, he shuts his eyes. CU Cosmo Lang, expressionless. CU Elizabeth, dying. Bertie gulps for air like a beached fish and attempts to continue: BERTIE (CONT’D) ...the King, the following gracious message... He can’t get the word out. SPLAT...the first drops of rai begin to fall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Establishing shot of an imposing Georgian edifice, opposi Hyde Park Corner. In the foreground people pay their resp at the WWI monument with fresh wreaths. A Rover sedan - definitive doctor’s car of the era - arri A FOOTMAN scurries down the steps to meet it as the STEWA opens the front door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON SIR BLANDINE-BENTHAM - an elderly, unctuous, studiedly-distinguished physician who simultaneously mana to combine pontificating and obsequiousness.

dialogues.speaker: SIR BLANDINE-BENTHAM
dialogues.text: Inhale deep into your lungs. Relaxes your larynx, does it not? Bertie is seated nervously on the edge of a couch, grippi cigarette between thumb and forefinger, placed in the mid of his mouth. Elizabeth watches from across the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cigarette smoking calms the nerves and gives you confidence. Bertie clearly feels nothing of the sort. Smiling ingratiatingly, the doctor produces a medical cannister f his bag.

dialogues.speaker: SIR BLANDINE-BENTHAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If Your Highness will be so kind as to open his hand... Bertie unclenches a fist.

dialogues.speaker: SIR BLANDINE-BENTHAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Thank you so very much. Opening the container, with forceps he removes five marbl from an antiseptic solution and places them onto Bertie’s palm.

dialogues.speaker: SIR BLANDINE-BENTHAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Sterilized. Now...if I may take the liberty?...insert them into your mouth. Bertie obeys, mortified. The doctor hands Bertie a book f his bag.

dialogues.speaker: SIR BLANDINE-BENTHAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Would you be so kind as to read. Bertie blanches, his neck muscles twitch and constrict

dialogues.speaker: I...
dialogues.text: He can’t even say “can’t”.

dialogues.speaker: SIR BLANDINE-BENTHAM
dialogues.text: Just take your time. Relax. Bertie is unable to do it. Elizabeth watches with growing discomfort.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Excuse me, Doctor. What is the purpose of this?

dialogues.speaker: SIR BLANDINE-BENTHAM
dialogues.text: The classic approach that cured Demosthenes.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: That was in Ancient Greece. Has it worked since? Blandine-Bentham passes Bertie a book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now if you would be so kind as to read. A wealth of words. Bertie tries. It is excruciating.

dialogues.speaker: SIR BLANDINE-BENTHAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Fight against those marbles Your Royal Highness. Enunciate! As Bertie struggles.

dialogues.speaker: SIR BLANDINE-BENTHAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: A little more concentration your Royal Higness. Bertie spits the marbles out.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: (explodes ) I nearly swallowed the damned things! Bertie storms out as Elizabeth tries to placate the docto

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Thank you so much, Doctor, it’s been most interesting. Elizabeth goes through to the adjoining room to find Bert INT. BERTIE’S STUDY, 145 PICCADILLY - CONTINUOUS Bertie is struggling to light a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Temper, Bertie darling, temper. Tick, tock, tick, tock.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Insert marbles! He can insert his own bloody marbles....! [Note: when he speaks with his wife there’s hardly any hesitation] Elizabeth smiles as she lights the cigarette for him.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: You can’t keep doing this, Bertie.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: I know. Promise me: no more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A thick grey wet blanket... Out of which materializes the moisture splattered hood of large AUSTIN. Elizabeth, inside, determinedly glances out. The vehicle noses thru a pea-soup fog. The York’s HOUSE DETECTIVE is walking a few feet in front of the car, find the way. After a moment, the House Detective signals the driver to stop. Elizabeth peers out the window. POV - in the gloom the least attractive and most ill- maintained of the Georgian terraced houses. Elizabeth looks disappointed and dubious. She gets out of car. Instructing the House Detective to wait outside, she enters the building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth enters, somewhat dampened, the white silk roses decorating her hat now limp. There is a cramped elevator which is whirring noisily and winding staircase. Elizabeth is even more dubious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth inside the cramped elevator. She surveys the buttons. The bottom one reads “Basement: Logue, Speech Defects”. She closes the inner gate of the elevator and presses the bottom button. Nothing. Confused, she opens the inner gate, closes the outer gate then the inner gate and presses the button again. The elevator jumps downwards. INT. WAITING ROOM, LOGUE’S CHAMBERS - CONTINUOUS Umbrella stand, coat rack, wooden waiting bench: that’s a She looks about. The area is devoid of life. Coughs. No response. Calls imperiously:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello. Is anyone there? From behind a door:

dialogues.speaker: MUFFLED VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I’m just in the loo. Princess Elizabeth is not used to this sort of thing. She further appalled by the loud gurgling of a toilet being flushed, and startled by the entrance of - LIONEL LOGUE - tall, middle-aged man with strong features. His demeanor friendly, yet professional.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: “Poor and content is rich and rich enough”

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: I beg your pardon?

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Shakespeare. I’m sorry, there’s no receptionist. I like to keep things simple. How are you Mrs Johnson? I’m afraid you’re late. Offers his hand. She takes it, a little gingerly.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: I’m afraid I am.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Where’s Mr Johnson?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: He doesn’t know I’m here.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: That’s not a promising start.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: My husband has seen everyone to no avail. He’s given up hope.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: He hasn’t seen me.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: You're awfully sure of yourself.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: I’m sure of anyone who wants to be cured.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naturally he wishes to be cured. My husband is required to speak publicly.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Perhaps he should change jobs.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: He can’t.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Indentured servitude?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Something of that nature.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Well have your hubby pop by...Tuesday would be good...to give his personal history and I’11 make a frank appraisal.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: I do not have a “hubby”. We don’t ‘pop’. We never talk about our private lives. You must come to us.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Sorry, Mrs J, my game, my turf, my rules.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: And what if my husband were the Duke of York?

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: The Duke of York?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Yes the Duke of York.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: I thought the appointment was for “Johnson”? Forgive me, your Royal...?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Highness.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Your Royal Highness.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Johnson was used during the Great War when the Navy didn’t want the enemy to know ‘he’ was aboard. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pause. EXT. 10

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We are operating under the strictest of confidences.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Of course. I’m considered the enemy?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: You will be if you remain un- obliging.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: How did you find me?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: The President of the Speech Therapists Society.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Eileen McCleod? She’s a sport.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Dr McCleod warned me your antipodean methods were “unorthodox and controversial”. I warned her...they were not my favorite words.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: I succeed.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: So she says.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: I can cure your husband. But for my method to work there must be trust and total equality in the safety of my consultation room. No exceptions.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Well then, in that case...

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: When can you start?

dialogues.speaker: SOUTH KENSINGTON STREET
dialogues.text: A well-used Morris Oxford pulls up, driven by Lionel’s el son - LAURIE. Lionel is the passenger. As he gets out:

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Still sounds a bit rough.  11

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: You make me drive too slowly, Dad!

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Did you pick mum up from Bridge?

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: Yes, I’ve hardly been out of the car all day. They enter a modest dwelling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lionel and MYRTLE are finishing up at the table with thei three sons. As well as Laurie and ANTONY, there’s their studious middle son VALENTINE, 17, his nose buried in a s of science books. Lionel is bursting to tell Myrtle something.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: I had a special visitor today.

dialogues.speaker: ANTONY
dialogues.text: May I be excused?

dialogues.speaker: MYRTLE
dialogues.text: (to Lionel) Oh yes?

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: You must stay, bored stupid, listening to your parents’ inane conversation.

dialogues.speaker: ANTONY
dialogues.text: (grinning) Thanks, dad!

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: And mum.

dialogues.speaker: ANTONY
dialogues.text: And mum!

dialogues.speaker: MYRTLE
dialogues.text: How special is special?

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: Me too?

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: A girl?

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: What else?  12 He and Antony start to leave.

dialogues.speaker: MYRTLE
dialogues.text: Take your plates.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Special to the point of someone I can’t really talk about. The boys grabs their plates and exit. Lionel looks at Valentine, nose still buried in his text. LIONEL (CONT’D) Doctor? Doctor? You can go as well.

dialogues.speaker: VALENTINE
dialogues.text: (still studying) I’m fine. Lionel clears Valentine’s plate. Valentine goes back to h book and scientific oblivion.

dialogues.speaker: MYRTLE
dialogues.text: Not too high and mighty I hope?

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Aah. Antony burst back in, model airplane in hand, doing barre rolls with sound effects, bombing Valentine with a tea to

dialogues.speaker: MYRTLE
dialogues.text: Not someone who’d...call attention? Why bring it up if you can’t talk about it? Silence.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Myrtle, just a woman looking to help her husband. They realize from engine noises that Antony is under the table.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (trying to make light of it, not quite succeeding) And I had a ‘call’.

dialogues.speaker: MYRTLE
dialogues.text: Oh yes. Valentine looks up from his book.

dialogues.speaker: VALENTINE
dialogues.text: What’s the Illiotibial Tract, Dad?  13

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: If you don’t know, look it up.

dialogues.speaker: VALENTINE
dialogues.text: Right. Starts turning pages.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Could be fun.

dialogues.speaker: MYRTLE
dialogues.text: It always is.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: They're a highly regarded group. From Putney.

dialogues.speaker: MYRTLE
dialogues.text: I’m sure you'll be splendid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lights are on in the upper windows. A double-decker bus passes on the wet street.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Tomorrow, Chapter IV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PAN OVER THE BACKS of 36 impeccably groomed horses. It ta a moment to realize they are toy horses, lined up with precision.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ‘The Flight’.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Oh, to fly away! INT. CHILDREN’S NURSERY, YORK HOUSE - CONTINUOUS Elizabeth, fashionably attired for an evening-out, is cur on a bearskin rug reading to a little girl - LILIBET, 10 who claps her hands primly, and her younger sister - MARG ROSE, 5. As Elizabeth closes the book ("Peter Pan”), Bertie, hands in a tuxedo, comments:

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Weren’t they lucky! Within his family Bertie’s stammer is virtually absent.  14

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET ROSE
dialogues.text: Now Papa tell a_ story!

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Could I be a penguin instead? He drops to his knees and waddles. In his tux he looks li a penguin. Margaret Rose giggles, but is undeterred.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET ROSE
dialogues.text: Tell me a penguin story, please. Called upon to perform, the stammer returns slightly, but girls listen raptly, ignoring their father’s minor impediment, and it fades.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: There were once two princesses whose Papa had been turned into a penguin by the local witch. This was inconvenient because he loved to hold his princesses in his arms and you can’t do that if you’re a penguin, you have wings like herrings.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET ROSE
dialogues.text: Herrings don’t have wings.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: His wings were the shape of herrings. To make matters worse she sent him to the South Pole which is an awfully long walk if you can’t fly.

dialogues.speaker: LILIBET
dialogues.text: You can’t walk from the South Pole!

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Shh!

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Exactly. When he reached the water and dived in he found he could fly. Fly through the depths. So fast, in fact, that he was in Southampton Waters by lunchtime. From there he caught the 2.30 to Weybridge, changed at Clapham Junction and asked a passing Mallard the way to Buckingham Palace. He swam up the Thames and came out of a plughole, giving Mama, the cook and Mrs Whittaker quite a shock. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The princesses heard the commotion and hurried to the kitchen where they gave the penguin a good scrub, a mackerel and a kiss. And as they kissed him guess what he turned into?

dialogues.speaker: LILIBET AND MARGARET ROSE
dialogues.text: A handsome prince!

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: A short-tailed Albatross. With wings big enough to wrap around both his precious girls together. (He hugs them both together )

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Now time for bed.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Take the saddles of your horsies, brush them, feed them and to bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they leave for the night:

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Will she be there?

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: My brother’s insisting.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Is he serious?

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: About our coming to dinner?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: No. About her!

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: A married American? He can’t be.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: She can. By the way I think I found someone rather interesting. On Harley Street. A doctor.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Out of the question. I’m not having this conversation again. The matter’s settled.  16

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: His approach seems rather different....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a church or school hall, out of hours.

dialogues.speaker: MUFFLED VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Now? From the auditorium:

dialogues.speaker: DIRECTOR, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: Now! Lionel comes onstage.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: “Now...” (begins again) “Now is the winter of our discontent Made glorious summer by this sun of York.” His elocution is flawless. The acting is unconvincing. LIONEL (CONT’D) “And all the clouds that lour’d upon our house In the deep bosom of the ocean buried. Now are our brows bound with victorious wreaths; Our bruised arms hung up for monuments...”

dialogues.speaker: DIRECTOR
dialogues.text: Thank you. Lionel peers into the darkness, his eyes hoping.

dialogues.speaker: DIRECTOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Lovely diction, Mr...

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Logue. Lionel Logue.

dialogues.speaker: DIRECTOR
dialogues.text: Well, Lionel, I didn’t hear the cries of a deformed creature yearning to be King. Nor did I realize Richard the Third was King of the Colonies.  17

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: I know the lines. I’ve played the role before.

dialogues.speaker: DIRECTOR
dialogues.text: Sydney?

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Perth.

dialogues.speaker: DIRECTOR
dialogues.text: Major theater town, is it?

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Enthusiastic.

dialogues.speaker: DIRECTOR
dialogues.text: Ah.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: I was well reviewed.

dialogues.speaker: DIRECTOR
dialogues.text: Yes...well...Lionel, I think our dramatic society is looking for someone slightly younger and a little more regal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Yorks enter the tiny elevator. Bertie shuts the inner gate.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: (indicating outer gate) No, darling, shut that one first. Bertie gets the gates closed and Elizabeth presses the button.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: How did you find this...physician?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: (poker-faced) Classifieds, next to “French model, Shepherd’s Market”. Bertie tries to smile despite his mood, but doesn’t make job of it.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He comes highly recommended. Charges substantial fees in order to help the poor. (realizes) Oh dear, perhaps he’s a Bolshevik?!  18 INT. LOGUE’S WAITING ROOM - DAY Bertie and Elizabeth enter. She explains in a whisper:

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: No receptionist. He likes to keep things simple. Elizabeth glances nervously at the lavatory door.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (loudly) The Johnsons. From the inner office.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Finishing up. Elizabeth is relieved the voice isn’t coming from the lav The consultation room door opens and a young boy - WILLY comes out.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: You can go in now, “Mr. Johnson”. (then to Elizabeth) Dr Logue says...

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Lionel!

dialogues.speaker: WILLY
dialogues.text: Lionel says...wait here if you wish, Mrs Johnson. Or, it being a p- pleasant day, p-perhaps take a stroll. (to the consultation room) Was that alright...Lionel? Lionel appears at the door.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Bloody marvellous. You can stay here and wait for your mum. Mr. Johnson, do come in. Lionel nods at “Mrs Johnson”. The Yorks look at each other. Elizabeth takes a seat. INT. LOGUE’S CONSULTATION ROOM - DAY A different universe from the Spartan waiting area. A wor of books - piles of them spilling everywhere. Two slightl shabby, but comfortable armchairs. Well-worn Turkish rug.  19 Hotplate and two chipped mugs. Recording apparatus. Model airplanes.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: He’s a good lad, Willy. He could hardly make a sound, you know, when he first came to me. Lionel catches Bertie staring at the airplanes. LIONEL (CONT’D) My boys made those. Good, aren’t they. Please, make yourself comfortable. Bertie sits uneasily on an armchair. Lionel goes to sit a distance. LIONEL (CONT’D) I was told not not to sit too close. Bertie remains silent.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I was also told, speaking with a Royal, one waits for the Royal to choose the topic.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Waiting for me to commence a conversation one can wait a rather long wait. [Although Bertie’s stammer in the consultation room will fade, it is a gradual process. ] Silence.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Know any jokes?

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Timing isn’t my strong suit. Silence. They stare at each other.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Cuppa tea?

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: No thank you.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: I think I’1l have one. Turns on the hot plate.  20

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Aren’t you going to start treating me Dr Logue?

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Only if you’re interested in being treated. Please, call me Lionel.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: I prefer Doctor.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: I prefer Lionel. What’1l I call you?

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Your Royal Highness, then Sir after that.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: A bit formal for here. What about your name?

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Prince Albert Frederick Arthur George?

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: How about Bertie?

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: (flushes ) Only my family uses that.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Perfect. In here, it’s better if we're equals.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: If we were equal I wouldn’t be here. I’d be at home with my wife and no-one would give a damn. Bertie starts to light a cigarette from a silver case.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Don’t do that. Bertie gives him an astonished look.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: I’m sorry?

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Sucking smoke into your lungs will kill you.  21

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: My physicians say it relaxes the throat.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: They're idiots.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: They’ve all been knighted.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Makes it official then. My ‘castle’, my rules. What was your earliest memory?

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: What an earth do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: First recollection.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: (stammer growing in intensity) I’m not here to discuss personal matters.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Why’re you here then?

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: (exploding - stammer free) Because I bloody well stammer!

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Temper.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: One of my many faults.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: When did the defect start?

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: I’ve always been this way!

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: (quietly) I doubt that.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Don’t tell me! It’s my defect!

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: (calmly) It’s my field. I assure you, no infant starts to speak with a stammer. When did it start?  Bertie is Silence. tea. 22

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: (annoyed) Four or five.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: That's typical.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: So I’ve been told. (quickly adds) I can’t remember not doing it.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: That I believe. Do you hesitate when you think?

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Don’t be ridiculous.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: One of my many faults. How about when you talk to yourself? silent.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Everyone natters occasionally, Bertie.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Stop calling me that!

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: I’m not going to call you anything else.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Then we shan’t speak! The kettle whistles. Lionel makes himself a cup of BERTIE (CONT’D) Are you charging for this, Doctor?

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: A fortune. So, Bertie...when you talk to yourself, do you stammer?

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Of course not!

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Thus proving your impediment isn’t a permanent part of you. What do you think was the cause?  23

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: I don’t know! I don’t care! I stammer. And no one can fix it.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Bet you, Bertie, you can read flawlessly, right here, right now. Bertie snorts dismissively. LIONEL (CONT’D) And if I win, I get to ask questions.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: And if I win?

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: You don’t have to answer.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: One usually wagers money.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: A bob each to sweeten it? See your shilling.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: I don’t carry cash.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: I had a funny feeling you mightn’t. Logue fishes two coins from his pocket and puts them on t table. LIONEL (CONT’D) Stake you. Pay me back next time.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: If there is a next time.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: (nods ) I haven’t agreed to take you on. Logue has uncovered a piece of apparatus, a recording dev with earphones. He sets a blank disc onto the turntable a positions a microphone, then hands Bertie an open book. Bertie glares at it defiantly.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: I can’t possibly read this.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Then you owe me a shilling for not trying.  24 Furious, Bertie opens the book and reads, stammers badly gets worse.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: “To be or not to be, That is the question. Whether it is wiser...” There! He hands the book back to Lionel. BERTIE (CONT’D) I can’t read!

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: I haven't finished yet. Lionel returns the book to Bertie and turns to some recor apparatus on a nearby table. LIONEL (CONT’D) I’m going to record your voice and then play it back to you on the same machine. This is brilliant. It’s the latest thing from America: a Silvertone. He hands Bertie a pair of heavily padded earphones. Berti doesn’t want to take them. LIONEL (CONT’D) There’s a bob in this, mate. You can go home rich! Bertie reluctantly puts them on. Logue turns a dial. LOUD MUSIC is heard. Bertie takes off the earphones. The music stops.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: You're playing music.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: How can I hear what I’m saying?!

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Surely a Prince’s brain knows what its mouth is doing?

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: You’re not well acquainted with Royal Princes, are you? Bertie replaces the earphones. Again, the LOUD MUSIC. His mouth moves as he reads, but all that can be heard is the music.  25 Finished, Bertie takes off the earphones and the music ceases. Bertie reaches for the coins, but Logue snatches them. BERTIE (CONT’D) Hopeless. Hopeless!

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: You were sublime. Would I lie toa prince of the realm to win twelve- pence?

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: I’ve no idea what an Australian might do for that sort of money.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Shall I play it?

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: If you prefer, we’ll just get on to the questions.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Thank you Doctor, I don’t feel this is for me. He heads for the door. Logue puts the record in a brown p dust jacket and hands it to Bertie.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Sir? The recording is free. Please keep it as a souvenir? Lionel opens the door for Bertie and closes it behind him INT. LOGUE’S WAITING ROOM - DAY Elizabeth looks up at Bertie hopefully.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: No Elizabeth nods and rises. They walk towards the door together.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Ah well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Establishing shot in the snow.  26 A cold and commanding voice is heard:

dialogues.speaker: KING GEORGE V, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: For the present, the work to which we are all equally bound, is to arrive at a reasoned tranquillity... INT. THE KING’S STUDY, SANDRINGHAM ESTATE - CONTINUOUS The King’s study, which resembles an orderly naval captai cabin, except for a desk littered with stamp albums, has converted into an ad hoc broadcasting studio. KING GEORGE is a barrel-chested man with Naval beard and uniform. He is giving his Christmas address via the radio. KING GEORGE V (CONT’D) .--within our borders, to regain prosperity in this time of depression without self-seeking and to carry with us those whom the burden of past years has disheartened or overborne. To all, to each, I wish a Happy Christmas. God bless you. The red light next to him goes out, indicating the broadc is complete. Robert Wood, the BBC technician from Wembley stands by as well as an official photographer. King George V looks at Bertie, who is standing next to hi KING GEORGE V (CONT’D) Easy when you know how.

dialogues.speaker: PHOTOGRAPHER
dialogues.text: Sir? Bertie moves away and the photographer captures the King, seated at his desk.

dialogues.speaker: KING GEORGE V
dialogues.text: (to Bertie) Have a go yourself.

dialogues.speaker: WOOD
dialogues.text: Congratulations, Sir.

dialogues.speaker: KING GEORGE V
dialogues.text: Ah, Mr Wood. Splendid fellow. Chap taught me everything I know: let the microphone do the work.

dialogues.speaker: WOOD
dialogues.text: Sir.  27

dialogues.speaker: KING GEORGE V
dialogues.text: Thank you. Wood and the photographer take that as their cue to leave KING GEORGE V (CONT’D) Sit up, straight back, face boldly up to the bloody thing and stare it square in the eye, as you would any decent Englishman. Show who’s in command. Bertie regards the BBC microphone as though it were an al creature.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: D-d-don’t thu-thu-think I c-c-can. In the presence of his father, Bertie’s stammering return full form, his breathing short and shallow, the neck musc in spasms.

dialogues.speaker: KING GEORGE V
dialogues.text: This devilish device will change everything if you won’t. In the past all a King had to do was look respectable in uniform and not fall off his horse. Now we must invade people’s homes and ingratiate ourselves with them. This family is reduced to those lowest, basest of all creatures...we’ve become...actors!

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Papa, we’re not a family, we’re a firm. His father shoots Bertie a surprised look: does the lad h a brain after all?

dialogues.speaker: KING GEORGE V
dialogues.text: The most successful institution in history. Our cousins wear crowns throughout Europe. A dozen of them! Sitting on thrones is our business! Yet any moment some of us may be out of work. Your darling brother... The only wife he appears interested in is invariably the wife of another!

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: (tries to brighten things) He’s broken off with Lady Furness.  28

dialogues.speaker: KING GEORGE V
dialogues.text: And taken up a Mrs Simpson, a woman with two husbands living! Had the audacity to present her to me at Georgie’s wedding. I told him straight no divorced person could ever be received at court. He said she made him sublimely happy. I imagined that was because she was sleeping with him. “I give you my word we've never had immoral relations,” he replied. Stared square into his father’s eyes... and lied. Bertie groans. KING GEORGE V (CONT’D) When I’m dead that boy will ruin himself, this family, and this nation, within twelve months. Who’1l pick up the pieces? Herr Hitler, intimidating half of Europe, Marshall Stalin the other half? Who’ll stand between us, the jackboots, and the proletarian abyss? You? With your older brother shirking his duties, you’re going to have to do a lot more of this. (nodding towards the microphone) Have a go yourself. Bertie tries to read the King’s speech.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Through one of the m-

dialogues.speaker: KING GEORGE V
dialogues.text: Get it out boy!

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: ...m-marvels of m-

dialogues.speaker: KING GEORGE V
dialogues.text: Modern - just take your time - form your words carefully

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Science, I am enabled, this C-

dialogues.speaker: KING GEORGE V
dialogues.text: Relax! (off Bertie’s continued inability) Just try it!  29

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: ...this Christmas Day, to speak to all my p-

dialogues.speaker: KING GEORGE V
dialogues.text: (all patience lost) Do it! INT. BERTIE’S STUDY, YORK HOUSE - NEW NIGHT Bertie lies on a chaise longue, smoking.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: (to himself) Lying bastard. Bertie gets up and retrieves the recording he made with Lionel. He walks to a Victoria stand, lifts the arm, plac the steel needle. It slips and slides across the records surface, as steel needles do. But what he hears is poetic flowing: BERTIE’S RECORDED VOICE “To be, or not to be, - that is the question: - Elizabeth enters, unseen by Bertie and listens. BERTIE’S RECORDED VOICE (CONT'D) “,..whether tis nobler in the mind to suffer The slings and arrows of outrageous fortune, Or to take arms against a sea of troubles, And by opposing end them...” Hold on Elizabeth, stunned: Unable to hear himself, her husband speaks perfectly for the very first time. INT. LOGUE’S CONSULTATION ROOM - NEW DAY Bertie and Elizabeth have returned to the consultation ro

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Strictly business. No personal nonsense.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: I thought I’d made that very clear in our interview. Logue is silent, then:

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Got the shilling you owe me?  30

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: No I don’t!

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Didn’t think so.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Besides, you tricked me!

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: No, I showed you what you can do. (tries to get them to understand) What you’re asking will only deal with the surface of the problem.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: That’s sufficient. My husband has difficulties with his speech. Just deal with that.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: I’m willing to work hard, Doctor Logue...

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Lionel.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Are you willing to do your part? Logue considers, then tells Bertie:

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Alright. You want mechanics? We need to relax your throat muscles and strengthen your tongue. By repeating tongue twisters for example. “I am a thistle-sifter. I have a sieve of sifted thistles and a sieve of unsifted thistles. Because I am a thistle sifter.”

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Fine.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: You have a flabby tummy, we must build up the strength in your diaphragm. Simple mechanics.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: That is all we ask.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: And that’s about a shilling’s worth.  31

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Forget about the blessed shilling! (calm again) Perhaps, upon occasion, I shall request some assistance in coping with a minor event. Will that be agreeable?

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: That will be the full extent of your services.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Shall I see you next week?

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: I shall see you every day. On Bertie, reacting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Many different sessions, many different days, all in the consultation room. CU of Bertie’s mouth. Humming.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hum for as long as you like. Hmmmmmmmmmm. ~And when you're ready, “Mother”.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Hmmmmmmmmmmmmmother .

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Beaut.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: A simple outward breath. “FFFFF” Wait for the “aa”. “FFFFFather”. Just slide into it.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: FFFFFFFFFFFFather.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Feel the loosening of the jaw  32 Bertie and Lionel both have their individual hands claspe and are shaking them, vibrating their chest and loosening their jaw. As their jaws wobble, they omit a vibrating so

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Ahahahahhahahahahahahahahahahahah.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: (at the same time) Ahahahahahahahahahahahahahahaha,

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Bertie lies on the floor LIONEL (CONT’D) Deep breath. Expand your chest...lift your diaphragm...allow the column of air into your stomach...How do you feel?

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Full of hot air.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Isn’t that what public speaking is all about? Bertie inhales deeply.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Some fast cuts. Lionel handing him a cup of tea. Bertie d slow breathing exercises. Bertie shouting something in frustration.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: I will never get that.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Yes you can, come on, come on.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Bertie’s on the floor again. LIONEL (CONT’D) Deep breath. Hold. He turns to Elizabeth. LIONEL (CONT’D) Now Ma’am, while you are here, you could again be of great assistance. If you’d kindly sit on your husband’s stomach.  33

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Oh yes?

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Gently of course. Elizabeth sits gingerly on Bertie’s stomach, asking solicitously:

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Are you alright, Bertie? Bertie nods.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Now exhale slowly...can you feel that resistance, Bertie? Down goes your Royal Highness...inhale slowly...and...up comes your Royal Highness. Exhale and down. Yes. Inhale and up. You get the idea.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: This is actually quite good fun, Bertie.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Do it at home. Doesn’t have to be you, of course, but I thought he’d prefer you to one of the staff. Lionel encourages Bertie to move as he reads a joke out. LIONEL (CONT’D) Move, rock back and forth on the balls of your feet, keep the movement continuous and flowing.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Bertie stands framed by the open window. LIONEL (CONT’D) I want you to release the five vowel sounds, each to last no less than 15 seconds.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Aaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaa...

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: (tapping him on the diaphragm) Let’s connect the toned diaphragm with your relaxed throat. Ma‘’am, would you be so kind as to be the timekeeper?  34 Lionel hands her a stop watch.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: +... aaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaa..... High up in the wall at the back of the building, a Harley Street physician peers out the window.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Anyone who can vibrate loudly in full view of the world can learn to give a speech.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: That’s right, Bertie. (checking watch) Now Eeeeeeeeeeeeeeeececececeeeeeeeee... Lionel joins in.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Eeeeeeeeeeeeeeeceeecee.....

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Eeeeeeeeeeeeeeeceeecee..... The sound of “eeee” becomes the roar of machinery

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huge industrial wheels whir noisily in neutral as WORKERS line up dutifully to hear the visiting Royal. Bertie’s li move, but due to the racket he cannot be heard. Elizabeth watches in relief. A FOREMAN, trying to be helpful, signals. The machinery halts, the factory falls silent. At first, the momentum o speaking without being heard carries Bertie forward.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: I assure you that my wife and I... Hearing his own voice reverberate through the cavernous factory Bertie’s stammer returns. BERTIE (CONT’D) ...ar-ar-are glad to vis-vis- visit... Bertie pauses. Takes a breath. Relaxes. BERTIE (CONT’D) ..-are glad to visit this important manufacturing district and see for ourselves one or two of the industries which have made it famous...  35 He gets back into his stride, despite the silence. Bertie relaxes a little. From Elizabeth, a huge smile of relief. The sound of an approaching aircraft engine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bertie waits beside a shooting break, a stiff breeze whip his coat, as a small plane lands and taxis. While he waits Bertie practises breathing exercises. The cockpit canopy slides back and - DAVID - leaps out, removing his leather helmet and goggles, gold hair gleami a sun god descended from the skies.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Hello, Bertie. Been waiting long?

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Where’ve you been? Bertie stammers badly in the presence of his brother.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Been busy.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: So was I. Elizabeth has pneumonia.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. She’ll recover. Bertie shoots him a look.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Father won't.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I’ll drive.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUOUS
dialogues.text: David drives. Badly.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Old bugger’s doing this on purpose.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Dying? The vehicle almost careens off the lane. Bertie grabs the wheel and straightens it.  36

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Departing prematurely to complicate matters.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Oh for heaven’s sake, David. You know how long he’s been ill.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Wallis explained. She’s terribly clever. INT. KING’S BEDROOM, SANDRINGHAM — DAY The King is propped up in his armchair, wrapped in his favorite faded Tibetan dressing gown. He’s attended by si members of his Privy Council - ARCHBISHOP LANG, LORD DAWS his personal physician, LORD WIGRAM his private secretary together with RAMSAY MACDONALD, LORD HAILSHAM and SIR JOH SIMON. Also present is SIR MAURICE HANKEY, the Clerk to t Council. The King’s sons and daughter are in attendance. SISTER BL his nurse, stands beside the King. Lord Wigram is reading out the Order for the Council for State. The King constantly interjects. He is confused and frail.

dialogues.speaker: LORD WIGRAM
dialogues.text: ... whereas by letters patent under the Great Seal, bearing date of Westminster, the eleventh June 1912 his Majesty King George V did constitute, order and declare that there should be a guardian, Custos Regni, in the form of Councillors of State. Off King George V’s confusion -

dialogues.speaker: LORD WIGRAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s the order of the Council for the State, Sir. So we may act on your behalf. Wigram presents a tray with papers and pen.

dialogues.speaker: KING GEORGE V
dialogues.text: I’m still confused...

dialogues.speaker: LORD WIGRAM
dialogues.text: Approved.

dialogues.speaker: KING GEORGE V
dialogues.text: Thank you.  37 Lord Dawson holds the pen as the King makes his ‘mark’.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: Feeling a little better Sir?

dialogues.speaker: KING GEORGE V
dialogues.text: No. I’m not feeling any better. I feel dreadful. Queen Mary enters. KING GEORGE V (CONT’D) Have you been skating?

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN MARY
dialogues.text: No, George.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David is on the phone. Bertie enters.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I’m on with Wallis! (continues as though Bertie didn’t exist) I know, darling, a talk, even a lovely long talk, is a poor substitute for holding tight and making drowsy. Nor making our own drowsies either, as we’ve had to do far too often lately. (kisses the phone and hangs up) Wallis misses me terribly.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Mother says you’re late for dinner. David glares at a clock.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: She forgets Papa’s bloody clocks were always half an hour fast! He sets it back. INT. DINING HALL, SANDRINGHAM —- CONTINUOUS David enters and sits between Lord Dawson and Archbishop Lang.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (to Dawson) How is my father? I hope he is not in pain.  38

dialogues.speaker: LORD DAWSON
dialogues.text: No, no, he’s quieter now. The butler enters and whispers to Lord Dawson and Lord Wigram. They both exit.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN MARY
dialogues.text: If your father were well, tardiness would not be tolerated. None of this..unpleasantness would be tolerated Pause.

dialogues.speaker: COSMO LANG
dialogues.text: (to David) You know Sir, I appreciate that you are different from your father in your outlook and temperament. I want you to know that whenever the King questioned your conduct, I tried in your interest to present it in a most favourable light.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (ironic) I can always trust you to have my best interests at heart. Awkward silence.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN MARY
dialogues.text: All my children, at the same table.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Yes, Mama. Lord Wigram enters and whispers to Queen Mary.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN MARY
dialogues.text: It seems our vigil will not be of long duration. INT. KING’S BEDROOM, SANDRINGHAM - NIGHT Lord Dawson closes the King’s eyes.

dialogues.speaker: COSMO LANG
dialogues.text: We commend our brother George to the mercy of God, our Maker and Redeemer. Queen Mary takes her eldest son’s hand and kisses it. The Bertie the same.

dialogues.speaker: QUEEN MARY
dialogues.text: Long live the King.  39

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (very emotional) I hope I will make good as he has made good. David falls into his mother’s arms, sobbing. He runs from the room. INT. CORRIDOR OUTSIDE KING’S BEDROOM - NIGHT David stands, smoking. Bertie comes from the bedroom to comfort him. David looks broken-hearted.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: What on earth was that?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Poor Wallis. Now I’m trapped! INT. LOGUE’S CONSULTATION ROOM - NEW DAY Lionel is at his desk listening to the radio. A news read is talking about the death of King George V. Two of his sons sprawl on the floor. Valentine is studyin for the School Certificate. Antony, the youngest, is taki a break from homework, building a model airplane. He switches off the wireless.

dialogues.speaker: ANTONY
dialogues.text: Dad?

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: ANTONY
dialogues.text: Time for a Shake, dad?

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: (flattered) You sure? Allright put your thinking caps on.

dialogues.speaker: VALENTINE
dialogues.text: (looking up from his book) Go on, Dad. This was, and still is, a much loved ritual. Lionel disappears behind a door..

dialogues.speaker: ANTONY
dialogues.text: Bet its the Scottish Play.  40

dialogues.speaker: VALENTINE
dialogues.text: No, I bet it’s Othello. It’s always Othello.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL, (OOMING OUT)
dialogues.text: “Art thou afeard?”

dialogues.speaker: VALENTINE
dialogues.text: (Without even looking up) Caliban!

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Oh! For heaven’s sake.. that was a lucky guess!

dialogues.speaker: ANTONY
dialogues.text: Don’t listen to egghead. Go on, Dad. Lionel has a pillow stuffed into his jacket to create a monstrous hunchback. His acting, performed just for his l is quite magical.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: “Be not afeard; the isle is full of noises, Sounds and sweet airs, that give delight, and hurt not. Sometimes a thousand twanging instruments Will hum about mine ears; and sometimes voices, That, if then I had waked after long sleep, Will make me sleep again:” (to Valentine) Alright, clever clogs, what comes next?

dialogues.speaker: VALENTINE
dialogues.text: “,.and then, in dreaming, The clouds methought would open, and show riches Ready to drop upon me; that...”

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: (overlapping) ..-when I waked, I cried to dream again.” It’s such a sad thought. A KNOCK at the door. Lionel is not expecting anyone. LIONEL (CONT’D) Next patient must be early. You better go lads, I’m sorry. (to the door) Won't be a moment, Clifford.  4l INT. WAITING ROOM TO LOGUE’S CHAMBERS - CONTINUOUS The door opens. Bertie is on the other side. The two men stare at each other, not sure what to say.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Bertie, they told me not to expect you. (beat) Sorry about your father.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: I don’t wish to intrude.. (gesturing towards the consultation room) May I?

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Of course. Please come in.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: I’ve been practising. One hour a day. In spite of everything. (notices Lionel’s hump) What’s going on there?

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: I was, sorry, mucking around with my kids. Lionel hastily removes the pillow, tossing it away. Reali Bertie has entered the consultation room. INT. LOGUE’S CONSULTATION ROOM - CONTINUOUS

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Do you feel like working today? Bertie notices the plane left behind by Logue’s sons.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: A Curtis bi-plane.

dialogues.speaker: LOGUE
dialogues.text: I‘1l1 put on some hot milk.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Logue, I’d kill for something stronger.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: I wasn’t there for my father’s death. Still makes me sad.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: I can imagine so.  42 Lionel passes Bertie a brandy. Pause. They sit. Silence. BERTIE (CONT’D) What did you father do?

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: A brewer.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: At least there was free beer. LIONEL (CONT’D) Here’s to the memory of your father.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: I was informed, after the fact, my father’s last words were: “Bertie has more guts than the rest of his brothers put together.” He couldn’t say that to my face. BERTIE (CONT’D) (blurts) My brother. That's why I’m here.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: What’s he done?

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Can't say. I can’t puh-puh-puh... His jaw and throat muscles constrict.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Try singing it.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Pardon?

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Know any songs?

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Songs?

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Yes songs.  43

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: “Swanee River”.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: I love that song.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Happens to be my favorite.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Sing it then. Give me the chorus.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: No. Certainly not. (fascinated by the plane) Always wanted to build models. Father wouldn’t allow it. He collected stamps. I had to collect stamps.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: You can finish that off. Bertie eagerly reaches for some balsa. LIONEL (CONT’D) If you sing. (to “Swanee River”) “When I was a boy with David...upon the Swanee River.”

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: I can’t sit here singing!

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: You can with me.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Because you’re peculiar.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: I take that as a compliment.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: I’m not crooning “Swanee River!”

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Try “Camptown Races” then. (sings) “My brother D, he said to me, doo- dah doo-dah...” Continuous sound will give you flow. Does it feel strange, now that David’s on the throne?

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: It was a relief... Knowing I wouldn’t be King.  44 Reaches into his jacket for his cigarette case. Then remembers, puts it away.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: But unless he produces an heir, you’re next in line. And your daughter, Elizabeth, would then succeed you.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: “You're barking up the wrong tree now, Doctor, Doctor.”

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: “Lionel, Lionel." You didn’t stammer.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Of course I didn’t stammer, I was singing! (realises) Oh...

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Well, as a little reward, you get to put some glue on these struts.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: David and I were very close. Young bucks... You know.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Chase the same girls?

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: David was always very helpful in arranging introductions. We shared the expert ministrations of “Paulette” in Paris. Not at the same time of course. An uncomfortable silence. Too much has been said.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Did David tease you?

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: They all did. “Buh-buh-buh-Bertie”. Father encouraged it. “Get it out, boy!” Said it would make me stop. Said...”I was afraid of my father, and my children are damn well going to be afraid of me”. Lionel has been watching Bertie work on the model.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Naturally right handed?  45

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Left. I was punished. Now I use the right.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Yes, that’s very common with stammerers. Anything other corrections?

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Knock knees. Lionel waits. BERTIE (CONT’D) Metal splints were made...worn night and day.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: That must have been painful.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Bloody agony. Straight legs now.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Who were you closest to in your family?

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Nannies. Not my first nanny, though..she loved David...hated me. When I was presented to my parents for the daily viewing, she'd... The stammering produced by the memory halts him.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Sing it.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: (tunelessly) “She pinch me so I'd cry, and be sent away at once, then she wouldn't feed me, far far away.” (speaks ) Took three years for my parents to notice. As you can imagine, it caused some stomach problems. still.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: What about your brother Johnnie? Were you close to him?

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Sweet boy. Epilepsy...and...he was ‘different’. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Died at 13, hidden from view. Too embarrassing for the family. (nervous ) I’ve been told it’s not catching.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Do you want a top-up?

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Please. Lionel gets up to pour another drink. BERTIE (CONT’D) You know, Lionel, you're the first ordinary Englishman...

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Australian.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: ...I’ve ever really spoken to. Sometimes, when I ride through the streets and see, you know, the Common Man staring at me, I’m struck by how little I know of his life, and how little he knows of mine.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: What're friends for.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: I wouldn’t know. ARCHIVE FOOTAGE OF KING GEORGE V’S STATE FUNERAL The common man, and woman, en masse. Thousands of them, solemn in their bereavement. Funereal bagpipes wail, joining the measured drum-rolls. Ranks upon ranks of military personnel slow-stepping the ceremonial death march. Muffled cannons bark their salute. Startled, a large flock of blackbirds rise up and streak across the wintery sky. A Naval squad pulls a gun carriage that carries the King’ coffin draped with the Royal standard, on which rests the Royal crown topped by a jeweled Maltese Cross. On Whitehall, the gun carriage passes the Cenotaph.  47

dialogues.speaker: PATHE NEWSREEL ANNOUNCER
dialogues.text: All salute as they pass the Cenotaph. One million died for him...as King George died for them. We see naval cadets salute to their right. END ARCHIVE FOOTAGE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David, very solemn, Bertie - pale and fragile, their brot Henry and George all salute as they pass the Cenotaph. The crowd is silent. Lionel, Myrtle, and all three boys are part of the crowd, half a dozen rows back. Antony and Valentine have mirrors sticks to see over the heads.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: (whispers a running commentary to the boys) That’s the Prince of Wales. He’s now King because he’s the oldest. Lionel spots... Bertie, in the procession passing by. Lionel stares at him. Tries to make eye contact. In the m of this pomp and ceremony the immense potential importanc his client sinks in. Of course, Bertie doesn’t see him. LIONEL (CONT’D) Quite an irony...all this.

dialogues.speaker: MYRTLE
dialogues.text: Why’s that?

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: His children weren’t too fond of him.

dialogues.speaker: MYRTLE
dialogues.text: Lionel! What a thing to say. Where’d you pick that up?

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Heard it...at work. Lionel points, to distract.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Think the German will make it?  48 Return to archive footage, a contorted limping German is seen. The procession of dignitaries continues.

dialogues.speaker: PATHE NEWSREEL ANNOUNCER
dialogues.text: ....fifteen Kings of Europe and eleven Princes of the Realm are here...

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: “I sifted seven thick-stalked thistles through strong thick sieves. I sifted seven...”

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Bertie, isn’t that enough?

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I have to keep saying it. This is your fault. CHOP! CHOP! CHOP! The sound of an axe. Fallen trees start to litter the roadside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bertie and Elizabeth are dressed for a party. Outside, fa trees, and more falling. They’re aghast.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Five hundred year old oaks...removed to improve the view!

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Nonetheless...we must try to be pleasant towards Mrs Simpson.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: You know she calls me “The Fat Scottish Cook”?

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: You're not fat.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: I’m getting plump.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: You seldom cook. She gives her husband a look, but realizes he’s teasing. gasps and points: POV - more trees being felled.  49 BERTIE (CONT’D) I sifted seven.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Shut up!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A weekend house party. Drinks at teatime. Five or six fri dance to a gramophone. A couple are already drunk. At the epicenter, David, the very picture of insouciance, and WALLIS, clinging to his arm, dripping in jewelry. Wallis’ most attractive physical feature is her back, displayed f by her choice of dress. Surrounded by their entourage, th are the apex of chic. A FOOTMAN announces:

dialogues.speaker: FOOTMAN
dialogues.text: Their Royal Highnesses the Duke and Duchess of York. Elizabeth freezes as Wallis sweeps forward to greet them.

dialogues.speaker: WALLIS
dialogues.text: How lovely to see you both. Welcome to our little country shack. Elizabeth stares at her, incredulous, then sails past, announcing to no one in particular:

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: I came at the invitation of the King. Wallis is wrongfooted. Elizabeth and Bertie reach David. Elizabeth curtsies to David, and Bertie gives David a nod

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Hello David.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Hello Bertie. Hello Elizabeth. David kisses Elizabeth on both cheeks.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: I see you’re making some changes to the garden.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I am. I am not quite finished. David’s eyes are drawn by Wallis.

dialogues.speaker: WALLIS
dialogues.text: David!  50 She taps her champagne glass. A footman goes into action, but Wallis waves him off. Dav leaves instead.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (calling to Wallis) Just be a sec, darling! Bertie pursues him. One of the guests - WINSTON CHURCHILL - nursing a glass o champagne moves up to Elizabeth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth is standing in front of a canvas of George IV w Churchill arrives at her side.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Don’t tell me I behaved badly, Mr Churchill.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON CHURCHILL
dialogues.text: On the contrary, your Royal Highness. Etiquette decrees royalty must be greeted by the official host: in this case: the King. Not a commoner. You behaved impeccably. As always.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON CHURCHILL
dialogues.text: I’m always amused when you're referred to as being a commoner. As common as the Scottish kings from whom you descend.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Your flattery is profound. What is your agenda, Mr Churchill?

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON CHURCHILL
dialogues.text: (pause, then) Did she actually say what I thought she said?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: You know she did.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON CHURCHILL
dialogues.text: What is her hold on him?  51

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Apparently she has certain...skills, which she learnt in an establishment in Shanghai. Churchill almost spills his new champagne.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON CHURCHILL
dialogues.text: Mam, I’d not realized you were so well versed in such matters. They catch a distant glimpse of David hurrying down a corridor, followed by Bertie, determined to catch up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bertie catches his brother.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: I’ve been trying to see you...

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I’ve been terribly busy.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Doing what?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Kinging.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Really? Kinging? Kinging is a precarious business! Where is the Tsar of Russia? Where is Cousin Wilhelm?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: You're being dreary.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Is Kinging laying off eighty staff at Sandringham and buying yet more pearls for Wallis while there are people marching across Europe singing “The Red Flag”?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Stop your worrying. Herr Hitler will sort that lot out.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Who’1ll sort out Herr Hitler? David hurries down some stairs.  52 INT. SERVANT’S CORRIDOR/WINE CELLAR - DAY David is hunting for a bottle of champagne for Wallis in wine cellar.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: And you've put that woman into our mother’s suite?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Mother’s not still in the bed, is she?

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: That’s not funny. David finds the bottle he was looking for.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Wally likes the very best.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: I don’t care what woman you carry on with at night, as long as you show up for duty in the morning! He exits. Bertie follows.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: This is not just some woman I am carrying on with. This is the woman I intend to marry

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: She’s filing a petition for divorce.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Good God.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Can’t you just give her a nice house and a title?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I won’t have her as my mistress.  53

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: David, the Church does not recognise divorce and you are the head of the Church.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Haven’t I any rights?

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Many privileges...

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Not the same thing. Your beloved Common Man may marry for love, why not me?

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: If you were the Common Man, on what basis could you possibly claim to be King?!

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Sounds like you’ve studied our wretched constitution.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Sounds like you haven't.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Is that what this is all about? Is that why you’ve been taking elocution lessons?

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: I’m attempting t-t...

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: That’s the scoop around town. Yearning for a larger audience are we, B-b-b-bertie?

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: D-don’t say such a th-

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Young brother trying to push older brother off throne...Positively medieval.

dialogues.speaker: D-
dialogues.text: Bertie is completely locked. David heads for Wallis, leaving his brother totally distraught. He pours her a glass of champagne. She shows is pleased with him.  54 INT. LOGUE’S CONSULTATION ROOM, HARLEY STREET - NEW DAY Bertie stands shattered, lost in painful memory.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: All that work, down the drain. My own brother... I couldn’t say...I could say...I couldn’t say a word in reply!

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Why do you stammer more with David than you do with me?

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Because you’re bloody well paid to listen! The latter, angry, sentence is flawless.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: I’m not a geisha girl.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Stop trying to be so bloody clever!

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: What is it about David that stops you speaking?

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: What the bloody hell is it that makes you bloody well want to go on about David?

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Vulgar but fluent. You don’t stammer when you swear.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Bugger off!

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Is that the best you can do?

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Well bloody bugger to you, you beastly bastard.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: A public school prig can do better than that.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Shit then. Shit, shit, shit!  55

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: See how defecation flows trippingly from the tongue?

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Because I’m angry!

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Ah. Know the f-word?

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Fornication?

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Bertie. Lionel gives him a look.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Fuck. Fuck, fuck, fuck!

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Yes! You see! Not a hesitation!

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Bloody, bloody, bloody! Shit, shit, shit! Bugger, bugger, bugger! Fuck, fuck, fuck! A knocking on the wall.

dialogues.speaker: ANTONY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Dad? What’s going on?

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: (calls) Sorry. Finish your homework. Bertie laughs. LIONEL (CONT’D) Well that’s a side of you we don’t get to see that often.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: No. No we’re not supposed to really, not publicly.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Can’t joke, can’t laugh? (then referring to Antony on the other side of the wall) Let’s get some air.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: No Logue, I don’t think that’s a good idea.  56 Lionel throws him his hat and scarf.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Put on your spy clobber. EXT. REGENT’S PARK ORNAMENTAL GARDEN - DAY Bertie and Logue come into view talking. Bertie with his homburg pulled low, scarf wrapped high. The park is empty bleak on this winter’s day. One can feel the cold chill; puffs of steam punctuating their words like smoke signals

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: What’s wrong? What’s got you so upset?

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Logue, you have no idea. My brother is infatuated with a woman who's been married twice - and she’s American.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Some of them must be loveable.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: (shoots him a look) She’s asking for a divorce and David is determined to marry her. Mrs Wallis Simpson of Baltimore.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: That’s not right. Queen Wallis of Baltimore?

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Unthinkable.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Can he do that?

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Absolutely not. But he’s going to anyway. All hell’s broken loose.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Can’t they carry on privately?

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: If only they would.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Where does that leave you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know my place! I’1l do anything within my power to keep my brother on the throne.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Has it come to that? But the way things are going, your place may be on the throne.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: I am not an alternative to my brother.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: If you had to you could outshine David... Lionel reaches out and gives Bertie a pat of comfort on t shoulder. Bertie pulls back in offended shock.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Don’t take liberties! That’s bordering on treason.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: I’m just saying you could be King. You could do it!

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: That is treason! They face each other, as though in combat.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: I’m trying to get you to realise you need not be governed by fear.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: I’ve had enough of this!

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: What're you afraid of?

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Your poisonous words!

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Why’d you show up then? To take polite elocution lessons so you can chit-chat at posh tea parties?

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Don’t instruct me on my duties! I’m the brother of a King...the son of a King...we have a history that goes back untold centuries. You're the disappointing son of a brewer! (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: A jumped-up jackeroo from the outback! You’re nobody. These sessions are over! Bertie strides off in a fury. Lionel, equally angry, goes the other direction. Two men moving apart in the cold wintery landscape, the ground mist rising. The Lionel stops. Turns. POV - Bertie has disappeared from view. CLOSE ON LIONEL as he realises...he’s no longer therapist a man who might have to become King.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PARADE — DAY A car pulls up. A bundled figure hurries out and slips in thru the garden entrance. INT. BALDWIN’S STUDY, 10 DOWNING STREET - DAY Bertie is with Prime Minister STANLEY BALDWIN, a stocky m with his hair parted straight down the middle. Their conversation in progress.

dialogues.speaker: BALDWIN
dialogues.text: It’s not just because she’s an American. It’s that she is soon to be a twice divorced American, and the King can not marry a divorced woman. I apologize for the nature of this, but... according to Scotland Yard, the King does not possess exclusive rights to Mrs. Simpson's favours and affections, sharing them with a married used car salesman, a certain Mr Guy Trundle. In addition, it is rumoured that Hitler’s ambassador, Count von Ribbentrop, sends her 17 carnations every day...... Silence.

dialogues.speaker: BALDWIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Should your brother continue to ignore the advice of His Government, He must abdicate. Otherwise His Government has no choice but to resign.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Prime Minister, you’d leave the country without a government?  59

dialogues.speaker: BALDWIN
dialogues.text: Does the King do what he wants, or does he do what his people expect him to do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The family is listening to a favorite radio show.

dialogues.speaker: MYRTLE
dialogues.text: What’s the matter, love?

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Nothing. Lionel shrugs helplessly, glances at the boys.

dialogues.speaker: MYRTLE
dialogues.text: You look a bit blue.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Just trouble with a client.

dialogues.speaker: MYRTLE
dialogues.text: Oh yes.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Frightened of his own shadow.

dialogues.speaker: MYRTLE
dialogues.text: Isn’t that why they come to you?

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: But this chap...
