dialogues.speaker: MYRTLE
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: This chap truly could be somebody great, and he’s fighting me.

dialogues.speaker: MYRTLE
dialogues.text: Perhaps he doesn’t want to be great. Lionel is silent.

dialogues.speaker: MYRTLE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Perhaps that’s what you want.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: I might have overstepped the mark.  60

dialogues.speaker: MYRTLE
dialogues.text: Apologize, Lionel. Do you both good. Sometimes you do push a bit hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lionel is shown to a chair in the hall to wait. Footsteps echo. Bertie’s Equerry, dressed in military uniform, comes in. is scrupulously polite.

dialogues.speaker: EQUERRY
dialogues.text: I’m very sorry, Mr Logue, the Duke is terrible busy.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: I’m happy to wait. Or I could come back later.

dialogues.speaker: EQUERRY
dialogues.text: As I said, the Duke is busy. The steward opens the door. Both wait. Lionel reluctantly withdraws. INT. BERTIE’S STUDY, 145 PICCADILLY - NIGHT Bertie and Chuchill sit on either side of Bertie’s desk.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON CHURCHILL
dialogues.text: But there were other reasons for concern, Sir. He was careless with state papers. He lacked commitment and resolve. There were those that worried where he would stand when war with Germany comes.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: We’re not coming to that?

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON CHURCHILL
dialogues.text: Indeed we are, Sir. Prime Minister Baldwin may deny this, but Hitler's intent is crystal clear. War with Germany will come, and we will need a King behind whom we can all stand united. Silence. WINSTON CHURCHILL (CONT’D) Have you thought what you will call yourself?  61 Bertie struggles to speak with the shock of the question. Pause. INT. WINSTON CHURCHILL (CONT’D) Certainly not Albert, Sir. Too Germanic. WINSTON CHURCHILL (CONT’D) What about George? After your father? George the sixth. It has rather a nice continuity to it, don’t you think. DAVID’S DRAWING ROOM, THE FORT - DAY Bertie waits nervously for David. David enters, looking sunken.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: David! Thank God. You look exhausted! How are you bearing up?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Bertie. I have to go. The decision’s been made.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: I cannot accept that. You are in no condition to make that decision.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I’m afraid there’s no other way. I must marry her. My mind’s made up. I’m... sorry.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: That’s a terrible thing to hear. David, nobody wants that. I least of all. INT. — DRAWING ROOM, THE FORT - DAY

dialogues.speaker: DAVID, (V.O. RADIO FILTER)
dialogues.text: At long last I am able to say a few words of my own. I have never wanted to withhold anything, but until now, it has not been constitutionally possible for me to speak. A few hours ago I discharged my last duty as King and Emperor. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: DAVID, (V.O. RADIO FILTER)
dialogues.text: Now that I have been succeeded by my brother, the Duke of York my first words must be to declare my allegiance to him. This I do with all my heart. Bertie, Henry and George are there to witness David signi the abdication document. Silence. The scratching of a fountain pen. He finally signs his name. The others sign. Bertie signs. HOLD ON Bertie’s face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David sits at his desk on which sits a BBC microphone. As always he speaks with beautiful fluency.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID, (V.O. RADIO FILTER)
dialogues.text: You all know the reasons which have impelled me to renounce the throne. But you must believe me when I tell you I have found it impossible to carry the heavy burden of responsibility and to discharge my duties as King as I would wish to do without the help and support of the woman I love...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANOTHER WIRELESS being listened to by Elizabeth and Berti

dialogues.speaker: DAVID, (V.O. RADIO FILTER)
dialogues.text: --This decision has been made less difficult to me by the sure knowledge that my brother, with his long training in the public affairs of this country... Bertie battles his emotions. Elizabeth takes Bertie’s han supportively.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bertie is in full regalia of an Admiral of the Fleet’s uniform.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID, (V.O. RADIO FILTER)
dialogues.text: .--and with his fine qualities...  63

dialogues.speaker: DAVID, (V.O. RADIO FILTER)
dialogues.text: ..--will be able to take my place forthwith without interruption or injury to the life and progress of the empire. Grimly, Bertie gets in to a waiting Rolls. Framed in the window he looks terrified as the car edges from the curb. On the pavement, kept back by police, a crowd of onlooker On the edge of the group...Lionel. Bertie peers out of the window of the Rolls. Their eyes m Bertie looks away. The Rolls drives on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bertie waits nervously. At a signal from his attendants he enters the Accession Council Chamber

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Council is made up of Privy Councillors, members of t House of Lords, the Lord Mayor of the City of London, the Aldermen of the City of London and the High Commissioners some Commonwealth countries. Standing before them, Bertie is handed his Accession spee All of Bertie’s old symptoms reappear: the tightening of neck muscles, the protruding Adam’s apple, the jaw lockin

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: I meet you today in circumstances which are - Bertie has come to a complete muscle-locked halt. He bows head in humility. And shame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elizabeth is with her daughters, preparing for the move t Buckingham Palace. The girls are tidying away their toy horses.

dialogues.speaker: LILLIBET
dialogues.text: Mama, will we have space for our horses in our new home?  64

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Of course we will, darling, we'll have a palace of rooms. Bertie appears, still in full regalia, straight from the Accession Council. He tries to put on a brave front, but doesn’t quite work. He desperately needs the comfort of h family. He holds his arm out, expecting his daughters to run to h for a hug and kiss, his solace after the ordeal.

dialogues.speaker: LILLIBET
dialogues.text: (to her sister, on seeing her father) Curtsey.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Your Majesty. They remain where they are and curtsy formally. Bertie is devastated.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: How was it? Bertie shakes his head imperceptibly. INT. BERTIE’S STUDY, YORK HOUSE - NIGHT Bertie valiantly tries to make sense of his new dispatch filled with state papers, seated at his desk. It is late night. Elizabeth enters, in night clothes.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: I’m trying to familiarise myself with what a state paper looks like. He picks up a series of papers. BERTIE (CONT’D) A despatch from Mr Baldwin which I don’t understand a word of. David's finances. The Christmas broadcast - I think that might be a mistake.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Don’t do it then.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Plans for the Coronation - I think that’s an even bigger mistake. I’m not a King. I’m a naval officer. Its the only thing I know about.  65 And Bertie breaks down; fierce, wracking sobs. Elizabeth speaks softly, with growing strength, having already accepted and adapted to the situation.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Dear, dear man... I refused your first two marriage proposals, not because I didn’t love you, but because I couldn’t bear the royal cage. Could bear the idea of a life of tours and public duties, a life that no longer was really to be my own. Then I thought...he stammers so beautifully...they’1l leave us alone. She takes his anguished face in her hands tenderly.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But if I must be Queen, I intend be a very good Queen. Queen to a very great King indeed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Re-establishing shot. Two large cars wait at the curb-sid

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A knock at the front door. Two figures can be seen outlined in the frosted glass doo Lionel opens it. Bertie and Elizabeth are standing there.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Waiting for a king to apologize, one can wait rather a long wait.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: I’m afraid we’re slightly late. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: This is home. Myrtle’s at bridge. I’ve made sure the boys are out.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: (stepping in) It’s lovely. Absolutely lovely. Lionel pulls out a chair for her to sit down.  66

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Would you like some tea, Ma’am?

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Yes. I’1ll help myself. (then) Off you go now. Or must I knock your heads together? INT. LOGUE’S STUDY - CONTINUOUS The two men enter and sit down. A moment of uncertainty. Bertie blurts.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Here’s your shilling, Logue (puts shilling down) I understand what you were trying to say, Logue.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: I went about it the wrong way. I’m sorry.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Now here I am. Is the nation ready for two minutes of radio silence?

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Every stammerer always fears they will fall back to square one. I don’t let that happen. You won’t let that happen.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: If I fail in my duty... David could come back. I’ve seen the placards “Save Our King!” They don’t mean me. Every other monarch in history succeeded someone who was dead, or about to be. My predecessor is not only alive, but very much so. What a bloody mess! I can’t even give them a Christmas Speech.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Like your Dad used to do?

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Precisely.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Your father. He’s not here.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Yes he is. He’s on that bloody shilling I gave you.  67

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Easy enough to give away. You don’t have to carry him around in your pocket. Or your brother. You don’t need to be afraid of things you were afraid of when you were five. A pause - LIONEL (CONT’D) You're very much your own man, Bertie. Your face is next, mate. There’s a noise outside the door.

dialogues.speaker: MYRTLE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Lionel?

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Myrtle! Lionel stands and pressed himself up against the wall.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Are you alright, Lionel?

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Yes. Bertie stands and makes towards the door.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Shall we go through?

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: (not moving) Trust me it’s important.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Myrtle has entered, she is flabbergasted.

dialogues.speaker: MYRTLE
dialogues.text: Your... your...

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: It’s “Your Majesty”, the first time. After that, “Ma’am”, as in ham, not Ma’lm as in palm.  68 INT. LOGUE’S STUDY - CONTINUOUS Lionel, still pressed against the wall, is explaining his reticence to Bertie.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: I haven’t told her.. about us. Sit down, relax. Bertie, bemused, sits.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: I’m informed your husband calls my husband Bertie and my husband calls your husband Lionel. I trust you won’t call me Liz.

dialogues.speaker: MYRTLE
dialogues.text: Your Majesty, you may call me Mrs Logue, Ma’am.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Very nice to meet you, Mrs Logue Myrtle is taken aback. INT. LOGUE’S STUDY - CONTINUOUS The men listen to their wives’ conversation.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Logue, we can’t stay here all day.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Yes we can.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Logue..

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Look, I need to wait for the opportune moment.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: (realizing) You’re being a coward!

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: You’re damn right. Decisive, Bertie stands and throws open the door.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Get out there, man!  69 And Bertie ushers Lionel into the parlour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Logue enters, pretending total innocence and surprise, followed by Bertie.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Oh! Hello, Myrtle darling! You're early.(indicating Elizabeth) I believe you two have met! I don’t believe you know....King George VI?

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: It’s very nice to meet you. Myrtle stares at Lionel and takes her revenge.

dialogues.speaker: MYRTLE
dialogues.text: Will their Majesties be staying for dinner? Logue and Bertie look panic-stricken. Elizabeth comes to rescue.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: We would love to, such a treat, but alas...a previous engagement. What a pity. On Lionel’s relief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To establish. Preparations are being made in the street f the coronation - spectator stands are complete and fabric being dressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The center piece of the Coronation staging is the throne Edward the Confessor. Scaffolding has been erected to sup seating. Technicians work to erect film cameras, lights, radio microphones. They stop short as they see Cosmo Lang waiting to greet t flanked by the Dean of Westminster and a couple of flunki There is a distinct drop in temperature.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Archbishop.  70

dialogues.speaker: COSMO LANG
dialogues.text: Welcome your Majesty. (referring to the cathedral, but it’s double-edge) What a glorious transformation, Sir. I hope you’1ll forgive us if we continue our preparations. Allow me to guide you through the ceremony. They begin to walk together, Lionel a few paces behind. COSMO LANG (CONT’D) We begin, of course at the West Door, then into the nave.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: I see all your pronouncements are to be broadcast, Archbishop. Cosmo sees Bertie staring at the microphones.

dialogues.speaker: COSMO LANG
dialogues.text: Ah, yes, wireless is indeed a Pandora’s Box. I’m afraid I’ve also had to permit the newsreel cameras. The product of which I shall personally edit.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Without momentary hesitation.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Doctor Lionel Logue of Harley Street, my speech specialist.

dialogues.speaker: COSMO LANG
dialogues.text: Specialist?! Had I known Your Majesty was seeking assistance I would’ve made my own recommendation.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Dr. Logue is to be present at the Coronation.

dialogues.speaker: COSMO LANG
dialogues.text: Well of course I shall speak to the Dean, but it will be extremely difficult.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: I should like the Doctor to be seated in the King’s Box.

dialogues.speaker: COSMO LANG
dialogues.text: But members of your Family will be seated there, Sir.  71

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: That why it’s suitable.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: And now, if you don’t mind, we need the premises.

dialogues.speaker: COSMO LANG
dialogues.text: My dear fellow, this is Westminster Abbey! The Church must prepare his Majesty.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: My preparations for Bertie are equally important. The two men stare each other down. LIONEL (CONT’D) With complete privacy. If you don’t mind.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Those are my wishes, Your Grace.

dialogues.speaker: COSMO LANG
dialogues.text: (sniffs) I shall place the Abbey at Your Majesty’s disposal...this evening. Your Majesty. Lang nods curtly and exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Footsteps resonate. Lionel enters. Ahead, he sees Cosmo Lang quietly conferri with Bertie. As Lionel approached, Cosmo Lang slips away. Bertie, Pause-—

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: I can’t believe I’m walking on Chaucer and Handel and Dickens. Everything alright? Let’s get cracking. seated on a ceremonial chair, does not rise.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: I’m not here to rehearse, Doctor Logue. BERTIE (CONT’D) True, you never called yourself ‘Doctor’. I did that for you. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 72 BERTIE (CONT’D) No diploma, no training, no qualifications. Just a great deal of nerve.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Ah, the star chamber inquisition, is it?

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: You asked for trust and total equality.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Bertie, I heard you at Wembley, I was there. I heard you. My son Laurie said “Do you think you could help that poor man?” I replied “If I had the chance”.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: What, as a failed actor!?

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: It’s true, I’m not a doctor, and yes I acted a bit, recited in pubs and taught elocution in schools. When the Great War came, our boys were pouring back from the front, shell-shocked and unable to speak and somebody said, “Lionel, you’re very good at all this speech stuff. Do you think you could possibly help these poor buggers”. I did muscle therapy, exercise, relaxation, but I knew I had to go deeper. Those poor young blokes had cried out in fear, and no-one was listening to them. My job was to give them faith in their voice and let them know that a friend was listening. That must ring a few bells with you, Bertie.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: You give a very noble account of yourself.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Make inquiries. It’s all true.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Inquiries have been made! You have no idea who I have breathing down my neck. I vouched for you and you have no credentials.  73

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: But lots of success! I can’t show you a certificate - there was no training then. All I know I know by experience, and that war was some experience. May plaque says, ‘L. Logue, Speech Defects’. No Dr., no letters after my name. (with mock seriousness) Lock me in the Tower.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: I would if I could!

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: On what charge?

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Fraud! With war looming, you've saddle this nation with a voiceless King. Destroyed the happiness of my family...all for the sake of ensnaring a star patient you knew you couldn’t possibly assist! His desperation spills out. He pulls himself out the chai striding past Lionel. BERTIE (CONT’D) It'll be like mad King George the Third, there’ll be Mad King George the Stammerer, who let his people down so badly in their hour of need! Lionel sits down on the chair of Edward the Confessor. BERTIE (CONT’D) What’re you doing? Get up! You can’t sit there! Overlapping-

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Why not? It’s a chair.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: No, it’s not, that is Saint Edward’s Chair-

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: People have carved their initials into it!

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: That chair is the seat on which every King and Queen-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s held in place by a large rock!

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: That is the Stone of Scone, you are trivialising everything-

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: I don’t care. I don’t care how many Royal arses have sat in this chair- Overlapping-

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Listen to me... !

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Listen to you?! By what right?

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Divine right, if you must! I’m your King!!!

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Noooo you’re not! Told me so yourself. Said you didn’t want it. So why should I waste my time listening to you?

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Because I have a right to be heard!

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Heard as what?!

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: A man! I HAVE A VOICE!!!

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: (quietly) Yes you do. You have such perseverance, Bertie, you’re the bravest man I know. And you’1l make a bloody good king. Bertie stares at him. A familiar voice is heard from the shadows.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: What on earth’s going on, Sir?

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: It’s all right, Archbishop. The Archbishop of Canterbury. 74  75

dialogues.speaker: COSMO LANG
dialogues.text: Mr Logue, you should know that I have found a replacement English specialist with impeccable credentials. Hence, your services will no longer be required.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: I’m sorry?

dialogues.speaker: COSMO LANG
dialogues.text: Your Majesty’s function is to consult and be advised. You didn’t consult, but you’ve just been advised.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Now I advise you: in this personal matter I will make my own decision.

dialogues.speaker: COSMO LANG
dialogues.text: My concern is for the head upon which I must place the crown.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: I appreciate that Archbishop, but it’s my head!

dialogues.speaker: COSMO LANG
dialogues.text: Your humble servant. Lang turns on his heel and is gone, leaving Bertie shaken with both anger, and fear.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Thank you Bertie. Shall we rehearse? Bertie sits in the ceremonial chair once more. LIONEL (CONT’D) As soon as you and Elizabeth enter the West door, you’ll be greeted with the hymn “I Was Glad When They Said Unto Me.” You won’t actually be that glad, because they sing it for a great long time. Then your friend the Archbishop will ponce up and say, “Sir, is Your Majesty willing to take The Oath?” You say..

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: “IT am willing”.  76

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Course you are! I’1l see what it sounds like from the cheap seats so even your old nanny can hear. “Will you govern your peoples of Great Britain, Ireland, Canada, Australia and New Zealand according to their lands and customs?”

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: "I solemnly promise so do so."

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: LOUDER! I can’t hear you up the back.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: “I SOLEMNLY PROMISE TO DO SO!”

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Very good! "Will you to your power cause Law and Justice, in Mercy, to be executed in all your judgements?"

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: "I will." “I WILL!”

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Then a long bit about upholding the faith, rubbish, rubbish, rubbish. To which you finally say...

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: “These things which I have herebefore promised, I will perform and keep. So help me God.”

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: That’s all you have to say. Four short responses, kiss the book and sign the oath. There you are: you’re King. Easy. The faint CLICKING WHIR of a film projector is heard. INT. SCREENING ROOM, BUCKINGHAM PALACE — NEW DAY On the screen: archive - Pathe newsreel footage of the Coronation. The Royal Family watches: Bertie, Elizabeth, Lilibet and Margaret. Cosmo Lang and his assistant are in attendance. There is a projectionist also.  77

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET ROSE
dialogues.text: You nearly crowned him backwards Archbishop! Lang steps in front of the screen, eager to explain

dialogues.speaker: COSMO LANG
dialogues.text: Someone had removed the thread that was marking the front of the Crown, Sir.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Try not lose the thread, Archbishop.

dialogues.speaker: LILLIBET
dialogues.text: (peering around Lang) Archbishop, your missing Papa. We see Bertie giving two of his responses.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Very good, very good. Archbishop.

dialogues.speaker: COSMO LANG
dialogues.text: Well, I hope Your Majesties are thrilled with the result. The Coronation footage finishes. The next segment of the newsreel is entitled “Hitler in Nuremberg!” and shows him viewing troops doing the goose-step amidst immense crowds then see Hitler’s mad eloquence, mesmerizing all. COSMO LANG (CONT’D) (to the projectionist) You can turn that off now.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: No, wait, keeping going.

dialogues.speaker: LILLIBET
dialogues.text: Do have a seat, Archbishop. They watch the footage.

dialogues.speaker: LILIBET
dialogues.text: What’s he saying, Papa?

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: I don’t know, but he seems to be saying it rather well. Off the roar of the crowds on the screen. Bertie’s face as he watches Hitler.  INT. MEETING ROOM, BUCKINGHAM PALACE —- NEW DAY Baldwin enters, looking pale and tired, to see Bertie.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Good Morning Mr Baldwin.

dialogues.speaker: BALDWIN
dialogues.text: Good Morning your Majesty. Congratulations on your Coronation. It went splendidly.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Thank you, Prime Minister. Luckily I only had to repeat a few short oaths. I may not be so fortunate in the future.

dialogues.speaker: BALDWIN
dialogues.text: Sir, I have asked to see you today in order to tender my resignation as Prime Minister.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: I am so sorry to hear that, Mr Baldwin.

dialogues.speaker: BALDWIN
dialogues.text: Neville Chamberlain will take my place as Prime Minister. It’s a matter of principal. I was mistaken. I have found it impossible to believe that there is any man in the World so lacking in moral feeling as Hitler, but the world might be hurled for a second time into the abyss of destructive War. Churchill was right all along. This was always Hitler’s intention. I am only sorry to leave you in this time of crisis. I am afraid Sir, your greatest test is yet to come. INT. LOGUE’S PARLOUR - DAY The Logue family are sat around the wireless.

dialogues.speaker: CHAMBERLAIN
dialogues.text: I am speaking to you from the cabinet room of 10 Downing Street. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: CHAMBERLAIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This morning the British Ambassador in Berlin handed the German Government a final note stating that unless we heard from them by 11 o’clock that they were prepared at once to withdraw their troops from Poland, a state of war would exist between us. I have to tell you now that no such undertaking has been received, and that consequently this country is at war with Germany. INT. BUCKINGHAM PALACE, BERTIE’S STUDY - DAY 3rd September 1939. Bertie, in uniform, is at his desk go through paperwork. HARDINGE, the King’s Private Secretary enters briskly.

dialogues.speaker: HARDINGE
dialogues.text: At last. Here it is. You are live at six. I’ve timed it at just under nine minutes. The wording is fully approved. The Prime Minister will be joining you for the broadcast which will go out live to the Nation, the Empire and to our Armed Forces.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Get Logue here immediately. Hardinge exits. Bertie is left contemplating the speech. Nervous as hell. INT. — LOGUE’S CAR - DAY Laurie drives Logue. Out the window he sees sandbags bein piled round government buildings.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: (peering up into the sky) Look, there are the barrage balloons. They got them up there quickly. An air raid siren is heard.

dialogues.speaker: LAURIE
dialogues.text: Should we pull over and find shelter?  80

dialogues.speaker: LOGUE
dialogues.text: No, just go straight on. We’1l be alright.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT./EXT. LOGUE’S CAR, OUTSIDE BUCKINGHAM PALACE Logue’s ID is checked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Logue hurries into the Palace. The car pulls away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Logue hangs up umbrella, coat and gas mask.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Logue is met on the stairs by Hardinge who hands him a speech.

dialogues.speaker: HARDINGE
dialogues.text: The King’s Speech. We have about forty minutes until the broadcast. Lionel hurries up the stairs. INT. BERTIE’S STUDY, BUCKINGHAM PALACE - DAY Bertie (dressed in his naval uniform) and Logue (dressed black tie) are rehearsing.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: (stammering very badly) “There may be dark days ahead, and W-w-wa...”

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Try again.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: “There may be dark days ahead, and Wr... ”

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Turn the hesitations into pauses, and say to yourself, “God save the King”.  81

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: I say that continually, but apparently no one’s listening.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Long pauses are good: they add solemnity to great occasions.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Then I’m the solemnest king who ever lived. Lionel, I can’t do this!

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Bertie, you can do this!

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: If I am to be King...where is my power? May I form a Government, levy a tax or declare a war? No! Yet I am the seat of all authority. Why? Because the Nation believes when I speak, I speak for them. Yet I cannot speak! As though none of this had happened:

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Let’s take it from the top. “In this grave hour...”

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: (hesitates, then) “In this grave hour fuck fuck fuck perhaps the most fateful in our history bugger shit shit (singing) I send to every household of my p-p- The letter’P’ is always difficult.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Bounce onto it ‘a-peoples both at home and’

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: “a-peoples both at home and overseas,...”

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Beaut.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: (singing) “,.. this message, doo-dah, doo- dah....spoken with the same depth of feeling...for each one of you as if I were to fuck shit bugger cross your threshold and speak to you m- my - ...”  82

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: In your head, now: “I have a right to be bloody well heard!”

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Bloody well heard, bloody well heard, bloody well heard myself!

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Now Waltz. Move! Get continuous movement.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: (waltzing and singing) “For the second time in the lives of most of us we are at wa - -" Bertie jams and comes to a halt.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Pause. “we are...” Take a pause.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: I can’t do this.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Bertie, you can do it. Have a look at the last paragraph.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Bertie...it’s time. Bertie and Lionel glance at each other. Bertie approaches the door. He pauses. Down a long perspective of rooms we see ahead the waiting microphone. Like a tunnel. Like Wembley. Bertie begins the long walk, flanked by his wife and his speech specialist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bertie, Lionel, and Elizabeth walk towards the microphone A corgi barks as they approach. The first room has a large speaker and chairs arranged fo listening to the broadcast. Lang, Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain and Churchill are in attendance.  83

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Prime Minister. Nice to see you again, so soon. Good of you to be here, I’m sure you’ve had rather a busy day.

dialogues.speaker: CHAMBERLAIN
dialogues.text: Let’s hope we have no more interruptions from those damned sirens, Sir.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Or the wretched dogs. (to Churchill) Congratulations. First Lord of the Admiralty.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON CHURCHILL
dialogues.text: Your Majesty.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: (nodding towards the recording room) The long walk. Churchill detaches himself from Lang and walks with Berti

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON CHURCHILL
dialogues.text: Good luck, Sir. I too dread this...apparatus. Had a speech impediment myself, you know.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: I didn’t.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON CHURCHILL
dialogues.text: Family secret. Tongue-tied. An operation was considered too dangerous. I eventually made an asset of it. A moment of silent recognition between the two men.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Thank you, Mr Churchill. Churchill nods, then goes to his seat, as Bertie passes i the next room. BERTIE (CONT’D) How long, Logue?

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Just under three minutes, Sir. Ahead is the microphone set up on a grand desk in a beautifully ornate state room.  84 Next to it is now revealed a stills camera and lights - a set for a photo op. Bertie, Logue and Elizabeth, ignoring it, pass right by, a corner and we now see a perspective of much smaller roo leading to a microphone framed in a doorway, hung at head height. A tumble of cables stretch through the rooms. We pass through two rooms of audio equipment with eight technicians all wearing black tie, all set for the broadc Bertie’s tension builds. At the door to the broadcasting booth he is met by the BB Wood. Bertie greets him

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Mr Wood.

dialogues.speaker: WOOD
dialogues.text: Good luck, Your Majesty. Logue, Bertie and Elizabeth enter the booth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dreaded BBC microphone, in a surprisingly small room. is arranged so Bertie can stand up as he speaks, the way Logue likes it. The ceiling has been lowered and it has b decorated in cheerful colours. As a podium for the speech old school desk has been propped up on wooden blocks so i the right height for Bertie. Logue immediately opens the window to get the air circulating. Bertie says nothing, but goes up and inspects the looming microphone. He spreads the fingers of one hand, touches the apparatus with the little finger, thumb to chin.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: I am thistle sifter, I have a sieve of sifted thistles and a sieve on unsifted thistles..

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: Bertie, darling, make sure it’s not switched on!  85

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Remember the red light will blink three times and then I’ve asked them to turn it off, because we don’t want that evil eye staring at you all the way through.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: I am sure you will be splendid.

dialogues.speaker: WOOD
dialogues.text: One minute, sir. Elizabeth steps back with a wonderful smile as Wood close the door, sealing Bertie and Logue in the booth.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: No matter how this turns out, I don’t know how to thank you for what you’ve done.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Knighthood? They smile.

dialogues.speaker: WOOD, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Twenty seconds.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Forget everything else and just say it to me. Say it to me, asa friend. The red light in the booth flashes. The red light flashes for the second time. Bertie concentrates. The red light flashes for the third time. The red light now goes steady red. Lionel opens his arms wide and mouths, “Breathe!”. On Air. Bertie’s hands begin to shake, the pages of his speech ra like dry leaves, his throat muscles constrict, the Adam’s apple bulges, his lips tighten...all the old symptoms reappear. Several seconds have elapsed. It seems an eternity.  86

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The technicians in their suits, ties and scientific looki white overcoats, wearing bulky headphones, monitoring daunting banks of valves and dials listen with growing apprehension to the silence broken only by crackling stat INT. KING’S STUDY/BROADCAST ROOM, BUCKINGHAM PALACE - DAY The tension is more than palpable. Bertie and Logue stare at each other. Logue smiles, perfectly calm, totally confident in the ma he’s worked with. His confidence is contagious. Bertie takes a deep breath, lets it out slowly. His throa muscles relax, his hands steady - all the things he’s practiced.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: In this grave hour, perhaps the most fateful in our history, I send to every household of my peoples, both at home and overseas this message spoken with the same depth of feeling for each one of you as if I were able to cross your threshold and speak to you myself. His cadence is slow and measured, not flawless, but he do not stop.

dialogues.speaker: INT
dialogues.text: In the listening room: Elizabeth grasps the sides of her chair and then slowly relaxes as Bertie’s calm, measure voice comes over the speakers.

dialogues.speaker: VARIOUS LOCATIONS
dialogues.text: The assembled dignitaries at Buckingham Palace, Myrtle wi two of the boys, people listening to radios in homes, pub factories. A group of soldiers, including Antony Logue. Q Mary sitting in her State Apartments, David and Wallis listening dolefully in a villa in the South of France, th crowds assembled outside Buckingham Palace, listening on speakers. Cutting continually back to Bertie as he grows confidence

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE, (V.O. ON RADIO)
dialogues.text: For the second time in the lives of most of us we are at war. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE, (V.O. ON RADIO)
dialogues.text: Over and over again we have tried to find a peaceful way out of the differences between ourselves and those who are now our enemies. But it has been in vain. We have been forced into a conflict. For we are called, with our allies, to meet the challenge of a principle which, if it were to prevail, would be fatal to any civilized order in the world. Such a principle, stripped of all disguise, is surely the mere primitive doctrine that might is right. For the sake of all that we ourselves hold dear, and of the world’s order and peace, it is unthinkable that we should refuse to meet the challenge. It is to this high purpose that I now call my people at home and my peoples across the seas, who will make our cause their own. I ask them to stand calm and firm, and united in this time of trial. The task will be hard. There may be dark days ahead, and war can no longer be confined to the battlefield. But we can only do the right as we see the right and reverently commit our cause to God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bertie, in his quiet way is totally in command, and utter magnificent. Everyone in the room is awed as he concludes BERTIE (CONT’D) If one and all we keep resolutely faithful to it, then, with God’s help, we shall prevail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the listening room we see the elated faces of Elizabet Churchill, Lang.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Technicians break in to spontaneous applause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lionel and Bertie stare at each other.  88 Silence.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: That was very good, Bertie. Lionel closes the window. LIONEL (CONT’D) You still stammered on the “w”.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Had to throw in a few so they knew it was me. Wood opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: WOOD
dialogues.text: Congratulations, your Majesty. A true broadcaster.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Thank you, Mr Wood. Bertie and Lionel pass out of the booth to the sounds of applause. They pause at the desk, which is set up with a microphone Bertie sits and has his official photograph taken.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Your first war time speech. Congratulations.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Expect I shall have to do a great deal more. Thank you, Logue. Bertie stands and takes Lionel’s hand BERTIE (CONT’D) Thank you. My friend.

dialogues.speaker: LIONEL
dialogues.text: Thank you... Your Majesty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bertie heads towards the listening room. Elizabeth goes to Bertie and kisses him tenderly on the cheek.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH
dialogues.text: (whispered, emotional) I knew you'd be good.  89 Elizabeth looks at Lionel.

dialogues.speaker: ELIZABETH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Thank you... (for the first time) ..-Lionel.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Onwards? Bertie continues on, and is greeted by Lang, Churchill an Chamberlain.

dialogues.speaker: WINSTON CHURCHILL
dialogues.text: Couldn’t have said it better myself, Sir The ultimate Churchillian compliment. Lang next.

dialogues.speaker: COSMO LANG
dialogues.text: Your Majesty, I’m speechless.

dialogues.speaker: CHAMBERLAIN
dialogues.text: Congratulations, Sir

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Thank you, Gentlemen. Bertie sweeps Lillibet into his arms. BERTIE (CONT’D) So how was Papa?

dialogues.speaker: LILLIBET
dialogues.text: Halting at first, but you got much better Papa. He kisses her.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Bless you. (picking Margaret up) And how about you?

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: You were just splendid, Papa.

dialogues.speaker: BERTIE
dialogues.text: Of course I was. Bertie readies himself to step out on to the balcony; wai crowds are glimpsed through the windows. Across the room, Bertie’s eyes meet Logue’s. A brief nod. moment of recognition.  90

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The King, his Queen and their children wave to the crowds receiving their adulation and love. Bertie glances upwards. POV - silver dirigibles hover protectively. ON THE BALCONY - Bertie and Elizabeth, King and Queen, wa to their people and receive their approbation. Lionel watches from the shadow.

dialogues.speaker: CARD
dialogues.text: King George VI made Lionel Logue a Commander of the Royal Victorian Order in 1944. This high honour from a grateful King made Lionel part of only order of chivalry that specifically rewards acts of personal service to the Monarch. Lionel was with the King for every wartime speech. Through his broadcasts, George VI became a symbol of nati resistance. Lionel and Bertie remained friends for the rest of their lives.
